title: About
text:
I‚Äôm an ecologist with a focus on biological invasions, digital ecology, and conservation communication. My work spans species risk assessments, horizon scanning, public perception studies, and open biodiversity data.
I‚Äôve worked in multiple regions including South Africa, Ireland, the United States, and the Czech Republic, collaborating with research institutions and policy agencies on applied conservation projects.




PhD in Invasion Science, Stellenbosch University

Former Postdoc at the University of Florida and Czech Academy of Sciences

Research Affiliate, University of Galway

Editorial Board Member, NeoBiota






Evidence-based conservation and policy

Transparency and reproducibility

Cross-disciplinary collaboration

Enhancing accessibility of scientific knowledge





I‚Äôm currently developing methods for integrating online data into biodiversity monitoring and biosecurity, including the use of Google, Wikipedia, Flickr, and other digital platforms to inform conservation decisions.

title: Welcome
text:
I‚Äôm an ecologist researching biological invasions and the use of digital data for conservation. My work spans species risk assessment, online public engagement, and the development of tools for horizon scanning and biosecurity.



I analyze digital traces‚Äîfrom geotagged images to social media posts‚Äîto study:

Invasion pathways and secondary spread
Cultural perception of invasive and extinct species
Applications of culturomics and iEcology
Risk frameworks and biosecurity decision-making





Canavan, S. et al.¬†(2023). Trending extinctions: patterns in online engagement with recently extinct animals. People and Nature

This study used Wikipedia and Twitter data to explore how public attention varies by taxonomic group after species extinction events.

See all publications ‚Üí

Running Code
When you click the Render button a document will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. You can embed code like this:

1 + 1

You can add options to executable code like this


[1] 4


The echo: false option disables the printing of code (only output is displayed).

title: News and Media
text:
GBIF data featured in research by Susan Canavan

Assessing potential causes of bamboo invasions
Published by GBIF, 1 June 2017
This feature highlights research led by Susan Canavan on the global spread of bamboos, which used over 23,000 species occurrence records sourced via GBIF. The study revealed that human usage, particularly the cultivation of multiple cultivars, is a stronger predictor of bamboo invasions than species traits alone. Traits like rhizome type, culm height, and diameter also correlated with introduction likelihood. The findings underscore the central role of human agency in shaping invasion risk.

Citation: Canavan S, Richardson DM, Visser V, Roux JJL, Vorontsova MS, Wilson JRU (2016) The global distribution of bamboos: assessing correlates of introduction and invasion. AoB Plants DOI:10.1093/aobpla/plw078

title: News and Media
section: Global biodiversity platforms in invasion science
text:
Global biodiversity platforms in invasion science
Mongabay Wildtech interviews Susan Canavan

GBIF open-source species location data supports global biodiversity analyses
Mongabay Wildtech, 31 July 2017
In an article on the power of open-access data platforms like GBIF, Susan Canavan discusses how digitized biodiversity records are indispensable for invasion biology. Her comments reflect on the challenges of curating global datasets and the importance of database cleaning for large taxonomic groups. The piece also includes perspectives from researchers around the world who use GBIF to model distributions and understand impacts of invasive species, land-use, and climate change.

‚ÄúEstablishing up-to-date inventories of taxa and their distribution is fundamental for invasion science.‚Äù ‚Äì S. Canavan

The article showcases Susan‚Äôs research on bamboo distribution and includes photographs of field and herbarium work, emphasizing the importance of digitized records and collaborative infrastructures for advancing conservation.

title: News and Media
text:
1 June 2017 ‚Äî GBIF Feature
I worked with colleagues to explore how bamboo species have spread globally and what drives those introductions. We used more than 23,000 records from GBIF and found that while certain biological traits matter, the strongest driver of invasion is human use.
üîó Read the full GBIF feature

title: News and Media
text:
31 July 2017 ‚Äî Mongabay Wildtech
In this Mongabay article, I discussed the value of open biodiversity data like GBIF for global ecological research. I shared insights from my bamboo study, the challenges of working with large datasets, and why open-access platforms are essential for tracking biological invasions.

‚ÄúEstablishing up-to-date inventories of taxa and their distribution is fundamental for invasion science.‚Äù

üîó Read the article on Mongabay

title: Susan Canavan, PhD
text:
I worked with colleagues to explore how bamboo species spread around the world ‚Äî and what drives those introductions. We used over 23,000 species records from GBIF to map global bamboo distributions and found that species with more cultivars and certain traits (like culm height and rhizome type) were more likely to be introduced. But above all, it was clear that human use ‚Äî not just biology ‚Äî was the primary driver of invasion.
 Read the full GBIF feature ‚Üí













In an interview with Mongabay Wildtech, I talked about the role of open-source biodiversity platforms like GBIF in supporting large-scale research. My bamboo project relied on global occurrence data that would have been impossible to collect independently. I also shared some of the practical challenges of working with big datasets ‚Äî like cleaning coordinates and resolving taxonomic issues ‚Äî and why those hurdles are worth it for the insights they unlock.
 Read the full article on Mongabay ‚Üí

We used over 23,000 species records from GBIF to map global bamboo distributions and found that species with more cultivars and certain traits (like culm height and rhizome type) were more likely to be introduced.
But above all, it was clear that human use ‚Äî not just biology ‚Äî was the primary driver of invasion.

title: About
text:
PhD in Invasion Science, Stellenbosch University

Former Postdoc at the University of Florida and Czech Academy of Sciences

Research Affiliate, University of Galway

Editorial Board Member, NeoBiota

title: About
text:
Research Goals
My goal is to develop actionable, data-driven tools to better anticipate and manage biological invasions‚Äîwhile also understanding how the public perceives and engages with species loss and ecological change.
I regularly collaborate with conservation scientists, digital ecologists, and policy agencies to translate research into real-world applications.

title: Welcome
text:
I analyze digital traces‚Äîfrom geotagged images to social media posts‚Äîto study:

Invasion pathways and secondary spread
Cultural perception of invasive and extinct species
Applications of culturomics and iEcology
Risk frameworks and biosecurity decision-making

title: Welcome
text:
Podcast: AmphibiCast ‚Äì Social media and extinction (2025)
Coverage in Daily Mail, Earth.com, and more

title: Research Overview
text:
Key Themes

Invasion Pathways and Risk Assessment
I study how invasive species are introduced and spread, and develop tools for horizon scanning and risk prioritization. This includes examining trade, tourism, and cultural pathways, and advising on management responses.



iEcology and Culturomics
Using social media, search trends, and Wikipedia data, I analyze public attention to biodiversity issues. These digital signals provide early warnings and insights into societal awareness of species and environmental change.



Digital Conservation Tools
I co-develop methods and open tools to monitor species distributions and detect emerging threats. These tools aim to support policymakers and improve public engagement with science.



Public Engagement with Biodiversity Loss
My recent work examines how extinction is communicated online and how people respond emotionally to biodiversity loss. I explore how these reactions differ by taxon, geography, and platform.

title: Tools
text:
suezalla is a lightweight R package that provides:

Custom ggplot2 themes: theme_magazine(), theme_latex(), theme_zombie(), theme_academic1940(), and theme_academic1940_pattern()
Several curated colour palettes inspired by polaroids, jam jars, retro aesthetics, zombies, and classic scientific graphics
Pattern fill utilities for ggpattern, including suezalla_academic_style()
Custom scale functions: scale_colour_suezalla() and scale_fill_suezalla()

These tools help you create clean, consistent, or stylistically bold visualizations with minimal effort.

title: Tools
text:
Installation

# If not already installed
# install.packages("devtools")

# Install suezalla
# devtools::install_github("sucanavan/suezalla")

title: Tools
text:
Available palettes




Palette


Colours






polaroid







vibrant







jam







corporate







lively1







lively2







retro







autumn







zombie







academic







npg

title: Tools
text:
Using palettes in code

# Return 4 discrete colours from the 'jam' palette
suezalla_palette("jam", n = 4)

[1] "#FBC9BE" "#DB7B65" "#ECB865" "#695356"

# Return 10 interpolated colours from the 'autumn' palette as a gradient
suezalla_palette("autumn", n = 10, type = "continuous")

 [1] "#388388" "#42A4A5" "#51BDB5" "#74B592" "#9FB578" "#D3BF6E" "#ECB867"
 [8] "#F2A562" "#EE8B59" "#E76F51"

title: Tools
text:
Fonts
The suezalla package auto-loads:

Roboto from Google Fonts for theme_suezalla()
XKCD (if available locally) for theme_zombie()
Abhaya Libre, Latin Modern Roman, and CMU Serif for academic themes

These are handled automatically via sysfonts and showtext when the package is attached.

title: Tools
text:
Quick examples

LaTeX academic plot

ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = mpg, y = wt, shape = factor(carb))) +
  geom_point(size = 2, stroke = 0.4) +
  theme_latex() +
  labs(
    title = "Car efficiency by weight",
    x = "Miles per Gallon",
    y = "Weight",
    shape = "Carburetors"
  )










Academic 1940

ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = mpg, y = wt, shape = factor(carb))) +
  geom_point(size = 2, stroke = 0.4, color = "black", fill = "white") +
  scale_shape_manual(values = c(0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5)) +
  theme_academic1940() +
  labs(
    title = "Car efficiency by weight",
    x = "Miles per Gallon",
    y = "Weight (1000 lbs)",
    shape = "Carburetors"
  )










Academic pattern style

df <- aggregate(wt ~ cyl, data = mtcars, FUN = mean)
df$cyl <- factor(df$cyl)

ggplot(df, aes(x = cyl, y = wt, fill = cyl, pattern = cyl)) +
  theme_academic1940_pattern(n = 3)










Magazine theme

ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg, colour = factor(cyl))) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  scale_colour_suezalla(palette_name = "corporate") +
  theme_magazine() +
  theme(
    axis.ticks = element_line(size = 0.3),
    axis.ticks.length = unit(3, "pt")
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Car efficiency by weight",
    x = "Weight",
    y = "Miles per Gallon",
    colour = "Cylinders"
  )










Zombie theme

ggplot(mtcars, aes(y = wt, x = mpg)) + 
  geom_point(aes(fill = factor(cyl), size = cyl), shape = 21, alpha = 0.8) + 
  scale_fill_suezalla(palette_name = "zombie") + 
  theme_zombie() +
  labs(
    title = "Car efficiency by weight",
    x = "Weight",
    y = "Miles per Gallon",
    colour = "Cylinders"
  )

title: Tools
text:
suezalla is a lightweight R package that provides:

Custom ggplot2 themes: theme_magazine(), theme_latex(), theme_zombie(), theme_academic1940(), and theme_academic1940_pattern()
Several curated colour palettes inspired by polaroids, jam jars, retro aesthetics, zombies, and classic scientific graphics
Pattern fill utilities for ggpattern, including suezalla_academic_style()
Custom scale functions: scale_colour_suezalla() and scale_fill_suezalla()

These tools help you create clean, consistent, or stylistically bold visualizations with minimal effort.
